div.text: The fallow land represented a new growing area for the species. Today, maize is produced in very high quantities, i.e. at values of US$ 25 billion (thousand million), which means 40% of the world's production, and 25 maize plants are needed daily to maintain the American style of life for each American citizen. During recent years, China has been the country with the most dynamic development of maize cultivation. In 2003, 114 million tons of maize were produced, the second highest quantity in the world after the USA. Brazil and Mexico are the next most important maize producers, although even the USA increased its production by more than 100 million tons during the last 30 years. Today, an annual 236 million ton production by the USA is the most significant component of the world's supply. The expansion of maize cultivation has not stopped; there are new acquisitions continuously each year. Yields as well as total volumes have recently increased significantly.

At the same time, the growing area increased at a much lower rate (9.9%) and the increment was balanced across the continents. In the future it is expected that the main cause of increasing yields will be due to the intensification of growing technologies rather than to the increasing area. The five "Great Powers" of maize production are the USA (40%), China (19%), Brazil (5%), Mexico and Argentina (3% each), whereas France and Italy produce 2% each of the world's total (Figure 1.2). Within Europe, France occupies the leading position (1.7-1.8 million ha, with yields of 10 t/ha) followed by Italy (1.1 million ha, with yields of 11 t/ha). In both countries, irrigation is an essential component of high yields. Mean yields of maize increased by 32% during the period between 1991 and 2005, but the differences are large according to the growing sites. Hungary occupies 13 th position amongst maize growing countries with respect to mean yields and 8 th position as to the increment of yields. Among the countries growing more than 1 million ha maize, the mean yields of Hungary are in 3 rd or 4 th position after USA, France (and perhaps Italy).

A careful prognosis predicts a further slow increase, depending on the growth of population. The leading countries will keep their position, but further exporting countries will appear (e.g. South Africa, Romania and Ukraine). Excluding figures for the EU's two maize exporting countries, a deficit of 10.7 million tons could be observed for the 23 other countries.

Against this deficit, available resources from France and Hungary totalled 12.4 million tons, resulting in a surplus of 1.9 million tons. But owing to imposed imports of 2.5 million tons from other countries (under WTO agreements) the total EU surplus reached 4.4 million tons.
The 2004-2005 campaign, the first with a 25-member EU, thus ended with a stock increase of 4.4 million tons (11 less 6.6), including an intervention stock of 2 million tons.

The main consumer was the animal feed sector (78% to total use). The vast majority of maize used is derived from domestic EU production with imports amounting to only 5% of total consumption. Imports are mainly into the animal feed sectors of Spain and Portugal, where price is the key factor influencing sources of supply.

EU maize farm level prices have been about 20% higher than US and Argentine farm level equivalents in the last four years but broadly similar to world market levels. Hungarian farm level prices have tended to be a little below the average in the leading EU producing country, France (Brookes 2005).

In 2006, European maize production faced a difficult situation, with 2005 cereal harvests (wheat, primarily) across the 25-member EU showing an increase of 10 million tons on 2004, against steady demand. Since exports outside the EU increased only slightly, end-of-campaign stocks continued to rise, with, again, a worrying level of intervention stocks (15 million tons).

In the economic year 2005/2006, 9 countries of the EU did not produce maize. The total production area in all 16 maize production countries is 6 million hectares, the volume of maize grown is approximately 49 million tons, whereas the average yield is 8.1 t/ha.
France had the largest yield production (its annual production is 13.230 million tons),
Starch and sugar 6% Fodder 89.5% The starch content of the maize kernel is 65%, which means first of all a source of energy.

The crude protein, mainly zein content, is relatively low (7-9%) and diminished in relation to the ancient open pollinated varieties. Oil content of the germ is 3-5%, appreciated as edible oil. Further chemical components are sugar (1.4%), pentoses (6.0%), fibres (2.0%), and minerals (1.2%). Quantity and yield are negatively correlated. Crude protein content is determined mainly by genetic and ecological conditions but N fertilisers may somewhat improve it.

The set of amino acids of the maize kernel is less favourable: lysine (2.8 mg%), methionine (2.0 mg%), tryptophan (1.0 mg%), glutaminic acid (15.7 mg%). Zein represents 45-50% of the total protein content. The Opaque-2 type of maize kernels contains 13-14% crude protein, but its yield is reduced.
